newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia companies seen restructuring tax arrears.
newsitem.headline: Russia companies seen restructuring tax arrears.

text.p: Russia's bankruptcy chief, charged with getting top tax debtors to pay up, said on Friday a number of major companies would probably restructure debts soon.
"The probability of a favourable decision (by the government on debt restructuring) is high," Pyotr Mostovoi, head of the Federal Bankruptcy Service, told a news conference.
He said his offices had sent 20 large tax and pension fund debtors notices on May 5 requiring them in a week's time to pay their tax debts or make debt restructuring proposals.
"About half the organisations took steps as advised -- either they paid debts, confirming that with necessary documents, or they made restructuring proposals."
The bankruptcy service will forward proposals to the government.

A government plan allows companies to restructure tax debts if they issue new equity comprising a controlling stake to be held as collateral by the state or company debt that can also be held by the government.

The Russian economy is struggling with massive non-payments and the government has proposed cutting 1997 expenditure by one fifth. The government has threatened to sue companies which do not pay or restructure with bankruptcy.
